title: 111_hr157
content: The Act titled "District of Columbia House Voting Rights Act of 2009" treats the District of Columbia as a congressional district. The District of Columbia is considered a Congressional district for representation in the House of Representatives. Amendments are made regarding the apportionment of members among states. Amendment made to clarify determination of presidential electors based on the 23rd amendment for the District of Columbia. Increase in membership of House of Representatives. The House of Representatives will have 437 members starting from the One Hundred Twelfth Congress, with reapportionment based on this new number. The President must transmit a revised statement of apportionment to Congress within 30 days of the enactment of the Act, and the Clerk must report on it within 15 days. The Clerk of the House of Representatives sends a certificate to each State with the number of Representatives they are entitled to. A report is also submitted to the Speaker of the House identifying the State entitled to an additional Representative. During the One Hundred Twelfth Congress, specific requirements for the election of an additional member are in place. During the One Hundred Eleventh Congress, an additional Representative identified by the Clerk of the House of Representatives will be elected at large from the State, while the other Representatives will be elected based on the existing Congressional districts. SEC. 4. NONSEVERABILITY OF PROVISIONS. If any provision of this Act or any amendment is declared invalid, the remaining provisions shall also be invalid. SEC. 5. EXPEDITED JUDICIAL REVIEW. If a challenge is made to the constitutionality of this Act or any amendments, the case will be heard by a 3-judge court in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. The final decision can only be appealed directly to the Supreme Court within specific time frames. The United States District Court for the District of Columbia and the Supreme Court must prioritize and expedite the resolution of any challenges to the constitutionality of the Act or its amendments.
